title: Quiz 5: Mitigation Strategies & Infrastructure
description: Assess your understanding of how to mitigate disasters through structural measures, economic diversification, and infrastructure planning.

questions.question: Mitigation activities fall broadly into two categories. Which of the following is considered 'Structural Mitigation'?
questions.explanation: Structural mitigation involves physical construction like dams. Policies and zoning are non-structural.

questions.question: Which of the following are tools used to prevent or mitigate disasters? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All listed options are tools for mitigation/prevention.
questions.hint: All of these are valid strategies.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ diversification is a mitigation strategy where economies dependent on a single cash crop introduce other activities to reduce vulnerability.
questions.explanation: Economic diversification reduces the risk of total economic collapse if one sector is hit.

questions.question: Match the mitigation strategy with its example:

pairs.right: Reducing dependence on a single cash crop
Situating warehouses instead of factories in flood plains

questions.explanation: Resistant crops=Adjusting development; Warehouses in flood plains=Resistant activity; Building codes=Non-structural.
questions.hint: Match the action to the strategy category.

questions.question: Investment in infrastructure for the management of hydrological hazards has significantly INCREASED the loss of life over the past 50 years.
questions.explanation: It has significantly REDUCED the loss of life (from 100,000 to 41,000 annual average).
questions.hint: Does better infrastructure usually help or hurt?

questions.question: When designing infrastructure for mitigation, which of the following is a key consideration?

options.text: Situating facilities to avoid flooding and unstable soils

questions.explanation: Proper siting to avoid hazards like flooding and unstable soils is crucial for mitigation.

questions.question: What type of mitigation refers to policies and practices such as land-use policies, zoning, and building codes?
questions.explanation: Non-structural mitigation involves policies/practices rather than physical construction.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of personal mitigation activities at home? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Strengthening structures and clearing debris are personal mitigation steps. Ignoring codes increases risk.

questions.question: Prevention is defined as activities taken to prevent a natural phenomenon from having harmful effects on people or assets.
questions.explanation: Prevention aims to eliminate the root causes or prevent the harmful effects entirely.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of disaster management?

options.text: To prevent disasters where possible or mitigate inevitable ones
To completely stop all natural hazards
To rely solely on international aid
To ignore risks until they happen

questions.explanation: The focus is prevention where possible, and mitigation where prevention isn't possible (since we can't stop all natural hazards).
